posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
No real issues.

The only thing you really have to contend with is your programmers using the right controller classes as that point.    On both teams I have been with we have mixed ecosystems at times  it isn’t a problem at all.

posts.name: Nick Wight
posts.cooked: Both teams I worked with this year ran three to four robots with full Kraken drivetrains and Spark MAX/Spark FLEX for the superstructure without any issues whatsoever. We did put the drivetrain on a separate CAN bus, but since the drivetrain is a self-contained subsystem and the CTRE Swerve Generator is so powerful, we felt no different from when we used MAXSwerve.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Leads to your code being a bit bloated due to having two different libraries you have to use/compile, but otherwise not the end of the world.

We ran a mixed environment in 2024 and our programmers were begging me constantly to swap out our two SparkMaxes for something that ran on CTRE code (they made it work because it was impractical to switch them, but still). Now that Talon FXS is a thing, even if we had to use a NEO, we could just run them on the CTRE controllers instead.

posts.name: Jim Foreman
posts.cooked: We used to run a combination of CTRE Swerve  for the drivetrain and SparkFlex/NEO Vortex for everything else. It worked fine, but when we standardized on CTRE everywhere the programmers threw a small party. Apparently it made their lives much easier.

I’m basically here to say the same thing as everyone else. Rev stuff will work but your programming team will like you better if you are full ctre. If you can afford it, go for ctre stuff. If you can’t, use the stuff you have and tell your programmers to cope. The rev api is slowly getting better and is not unusable.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
Not bad at all?

You can pretty much use whatever components wherever. Less reusable code, but that’s about it. Last year we used Kraken X60s for our drive base and Neo 1.1s for mechanisms.
